questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a history of hyperthyroidism is diagnosed with a brain tumor and is scheduled for neurosurgery. Thiopentone has been chosen as the induction agent for this surgery. Which of the following is an incorrect statement about Thiopentone?

choices.text: Thiopentone decreases intracranial pressure, making it suitable for neurosurgical procedures
Porphyria is a relative contraindication for thiopentone
The mechanism for termination of action is by redistribution from brain to fat cells
Thiopentone has antithyroid properties and thus is an agent of choice for hyperthyroid patients

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Porphyria is a relative contraindication for thiopentone

Explanation:

Porphyria is not a relative contraindication but an absolute contraindication for the use of Thiopentone due to the risk of inducing acute porphyric crisis.

Contraindications for thiopentone:

Absolute

Relative
  • Porphyria
  • Heart Blocks
  • Hypotension
  • Asthma

 

Thiopentone decreases intracranial pressure, making it suitable for neurosurgical procedures (Option A): Thiopentone, an intravenous barbiturate, is used as an induction agent of choice for neurosurgeries for the following reasons:

  • Causes maximum decrease in ICP
  • Anticonvulsant properties
  • Decreases cerebral metabolic rate
  • Maximum neuroprotective among IV anaesthetics

The mechanism for termination of action is by redistribution from brain to fat cells (Option C): The primary mechanism for the termination of its action is redistribution from the brain to fat and muscle tissues.

 

Mechanism of Termination

Redistribution from the brain to fat and muscle tissues

Metabolism

Metabolised in the liver by hydroxylation

Excretion

Excreted by the kidneys

 

Thiopentone has antithyroid properties and thus is an agent of choice for hyperthyroid patients (Option D): Thiopentone has antithyroid properties, making it an induction agent of choice for hyperthyroid patients.

All i/v anaesthetics cause :

  • Decreased Cerebral metabolic O2 demand
  • Decreased ICP and CBF
  • Decreased Respiratory drive
  • Myocardial depression

Exceptions KETAMINE: Sympathomimetic drug, increase all of the above
ETOMIDATE: Cardio-stable

questions.text: A 45 year old male undergoes a minor surgical procedure for lipoma excision under local anesthesia with bupivacaine. Shortly after administration, he complains of tinnitus, dizziness and a metallic taste in his mouth. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) 20% lipid emulsion therapy

Explanation:

  • 20% lipid emulsion therapy is the most appropriate treatment for bupivacaine toxicity.
  • Lipid emulsion acts as a "lipid sink", sequestering the lipophilic bupivacaine, thus reducing its concentration in tissues and mitigating toxicity.
  • Bupivacaine is a long-acting local anesthetic.
  • Toxicity often results from overdose or accidental intravascular injection, leading to serious and potentially life-threatening complications.

Mechanism of Toxicity
  • Lipophilic nature leads to slow dissociation/prolonged blocking from cardiac sodium channels.
  • Persistent channel blockage causes cumulative cardiotoxicity.

Symptoms
  • CNS: Tinnitus, metallic taste, dizziness, seizures.
  • Cardiovascular: Bradycardia, dysrhythmias, asystole.

Treatment
  • 20% lipid emulsion therapy acts as a "lipid sink" to reduce tissue concentration of bupivacaine.
  • Effective airway management is vital, especially in the presence of acidosis, hypercarbia, or hypoxemia.

Exacerbating Factors

Acidosis, hypercarbia, hypoxemia can worsen cardiac toxicity.

 

  • Intravenous atropine (Option A) and Intravenous epinephrine (Option B) may be used for bradycardia and cardiac arrest, but they are not the primary treatment for bupivacaine toxicity.
  • Intravenous sodium bicarbonate (Option D) can be helpful in managing acidosis, which may exacerbate toxicity, but it is not the primary antidote.

A 55-year-old male patient with a history of chronic kidney disease and liver cirrhosis is scheduled for elective abdominal surgery. The anesthesiologist must choose an appropriate muscle relaxant for intubation and intraoperative muscle relaxation. Considering the patient's comorbidities, the anesthesiologist is evaluating the use of cisatracurium instead of atracurium.

Which of the following statements is true regarding Atracurium?

choices.text: Preferred muscle relaxant in liver/ kidney disease

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Dose-dependent histamine release

Explanation:

Differences between Atracurium and Cisatracurium:

 

Atracurium

Cisatracurium
  1. Mixture of >10 isomers
  2. Metabolized by Hoffmann elimination and plasma esterase
  3. Dose-dependent histamine release ➞ allergy (Option B)
  4. Should be avoided in patients with kidney/ liver disease, as its toxic metabolite laudanosine gets accumulated ➞ CNS toxicity ➞ seizures
  1. Made of one isomer (Option D)
  2. 100% of the drug is metabolized by Hofmann elimination (Option A)
  3. No histamine release
  4. Safe in patients with kidney/ liver disease (Option C).

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency department for an urgent intubation due to respiratory failure. The anesthesiologist decides to use succinylcholine to facilitate rapid sequence intubation.

Which of the following statements is false regarding succinylcholine?

choices.text: Drug of choice in stroke and hemiplegia

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Drug of choice in stroke and hemiplegia

Explanation:

Succinylcholine:

  • It is a depolarising neuromuscular blocking agent
  • It is the fastest and shortest-acting neuromuscular blocking agent
  • Causes initial fasciculations
  • It is metabolized by pseudocholinesterase.
  • Its actions cannot be reversed by neostigmine.

Toxicity of succinylcholine:
  • Diaphragm paralysis ➞ Scoline apnea (Option A)
  • Hyperkalemia (Option B)
    • Due to potassium release ➞ cardiac arrest
    • Increased in trauma, burns, rhabdomyolysis
  • Malignant hyperthermia
    • Treated by Dantrolene
  • Histamine release
  • SA node partial agonist leads to bradycardia , junctional rhythm - treatment: i/v atropine

Contraindications:
  • Muscle dystrophy (Option C)
  • Neurological disease
    • Hemiplegia
    • Stroke (Option D)
  • Contraindicated in head injury, glaucoma
    • Increases ICP, IOP

questions.text: Which of the following local anaesthetics is used to diagnose pseudocholinesterase deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Dibucaine

Explanation:

To diagnose pseudocholinesterase deficiency, the local anesthetic used is dibucaine.

Dibucaine test to diagnose pseudocholinesterase deficiency:

  • A laboratory analysis for pseudocholinesterase deficiency involves taking a plasma sample from the patient and subjecting it to a qualitative test to assess the activity of the pseudocholinesterase enzyme.
  • Dibucaine is a long-acting & highly potent local anesthetic that inhibits about 80% of pseudocholinesterase (PChE) activity in normal individuals.
  • In heterozygotes (with 1 variant allele), PChE activity is inhibited by approximately 40-60%.
  • In homozygotes (with 2 variant alleles), PChE activity is inhibited by around 20%.
  • The percentage of inhibition is known as the dibucaine number.
  • A lower dibucaine number indicates a longer duration of residual neuromuscular blockade after administration of succinylcholine (SCh) or mivacurium.

questions.text: In the context of differential sensitivity of nerve fibers to local anaesthetics, which of the following sequences correctly represents the order in which different types of nerve fibres are blocked, starting from the most sensitive to the least sensitive?

choices.text: Type A alpha, Type A beta, Type A gamma, Type A delta, Type C
Type A delta, Type A gamma, Type A beta, Type A alpha,Type C
Type A delta, Type A alpha, Type A beta, Type A gamma, Type C
Type C, Type A gamma, Type A delta, Type A beta, Type A alpha

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Type A delta, Type A gamma, Type A beta, Type A alpha, Type C,

Explanation:

  • Local anaesthetics block nerve fibres in a specific order based on their diameter and myelination.
  • B fibres are the most sensitive and are blocked first, followed by small unmyelinated C fibres and small myelinated A-delta fibres.
  • Subsequently, A gamma, A beta, and finally, the large, heavily myelinated A alpha fibres are blocked.

questions.text: A 12-year-old patient was sedated for more than 48 hours following status epilepticus. He developed refractory bradycardia, hyperlipidemia, and renal failure. Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis showed metabolic acidosis. Which of the following sedatives is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Propofol

Explanation: 

The patient's presentation is indicative of Propofol Infusion Syndrome (PRIS), which can occur with prolonged propofol sedation. PRIS is characterized by symptoms such as refractory bradycardia, hyperlipidemia, renal failure, and metabolic acidosis.

  • PRIS typically occurs when a dose of >4 mg/kg/hr of propofol is given for >48 hours. Additional features of PRIS include:
    • Hyperlipidemia (first sign to get detected)
    • Refractory bradycardia and asystole
    • Acute renal failure
    • Rhabdomyolysis
    • Severe metabolic acidosis
    • Green-coloured urine can also be seen.
  • Recognizing these signs is crucial for diagnosing and managing PRIS, as this is potentially fatal.

Midazolam (Option A): While midazolam can cause prolonged sedation and respiratory depression, it is not typically associated with hyperlipidemia, metabolic acidosis, or renal failure.

Dexmedetomidine (Option B): It can cause bradycardia, but it does not cause hyperlipidemia, metabolic acidosis, or renal failure. 

Fentanyl (Option D): It can cause respiratory depression and hypotension but is not associated with hyperlipidemia, metabolic acidosis, or renal failure.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient is administered an intermediate-acting amide as a local anesthetic during a minor surgical procedure on the upper extremity. Shortly after administration, the patient develops cyanosis and complains of shortness of breath. Which of the following is most likely the local anesthetic based on the above symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Prilocaine

Explanation:

  • Prilocaine, a local anaesthetic, can cause methemoglobinemia, where haemoglobin is oxidised to methemoglobin, reducing blood’s oxygen-carrying capacity.
  • This leads to symptoms like cyanosis and shortness of breath. Benzocaine also causes methemoglobinemia
  • Methemoglobinemia typically develops after administering prilocaine at a dose of 8 mg/kg. Methemoglobinemia can be treated with intravenous methylene blue at a dose of 1–2 mg/kg.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about isoflurane is correct?

choices.text: Isoflurane primarily causes a drop in blood pressure through cardiac depression
Isoflurane maintains cardiac output while causing vasodilation
Isoflurane is known to provoke seizures, making it unsuitable for patients undergoing neurosurgery
Isoflurane causes significant metabolic byproducts, leading to renal and hepatic toxicity.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Isoflurane maintains cardiac output while causing vasodilation

Explanation: 

Isoflurane is particularly beneficial in patients with heart failure because it maintains cardiac output while causing vasodilation and reducing BP, unlike halothane, which primarily causes a drop in BP through cardiac depression.

Effects of Isoflurane:

System

Effects

CVS
  • Decrease in BP - due to vasodilation (Option A)
  • CO is well maintained - suitable for patients with myocardial insufficiency (Option B)
  • HR is increased due to reflex tachycardia
  • Dilates coronaries - possibility of coronary steal syndrome

RS
  • Respiratory depression
  • Increased secretions

Uterus and Skeletal Muscles

Muscle Relaxation

Ocular

Pupils do not dilate and light reflex is not lost.

Metabolism

Negligible - No renal or hepatotoxicity

 

  • It is also noted for its minimal metabolism, reducing the risk of renal and hepatic toxicity (Option D).
  • It does not provoke seizures (Option C), making it suitable for neurosurgical procedures (whereas sevoflurane provokes seizures and is contraindicated in neurosurgical procedures).
  • Agent of choice in liver failure.

All inhalational anaesthetic agents cause :

  • Decreased Respiratory drive
  • Decreased cerebral metabolic O2 demand
  • Increased CBF and ICP

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a history of asthma presents to the operating room for elective surgery. Halothane is used as the primary anaesthetic agent. During the induction phase, the patient suddenly develops ventricular arrhythmias. What is the most likely mechanism underlying the ventricular arrhythmias induced by halothane in this patient?

choices.text: Sensitization of the myocardium to catecholamines
Potentiation of calcium influx into cardiac myocytes

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Sensitization of the myocardium to catecholamines

Explanation: 

The patient's sudden development of ventricular arrhythmias during halothane anesthesia is most likely due to the sensitisation of the myocardium to catecholamines rather than direct myocardial depression or inhibition of catecholamine release.

Effects of Halothane:

 

System

Effects

CVS
  • Decrease in BP due to cardiac depression
  • CO is reduced with deepening anesthesia
  • HR is reduced
  • Sensitize the heart to the arrhythmogenic action of adrenaline/noradrenaline

RS
  • Respiratory depression
  • Bronchodilation - DOC for asthmatics

GI/GU

Inhibits intestinal and uterine contractions

↓BP → ↓GFR → ↓ urine formation

Metabolism

By liver - Hepatotoxic

 

Halothane can depress myocardial contractility by reducing intracellular calcium concentration, but this is not the primary mechanism for halothane-induced arrhythmias.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male is undergoing surgery for an abdominal hernia repair. Cyclopropane is chosen as the anaesthetic agent. During the procedure, electrocautery is used to control bleeding. Due to concerns about cyclopropane's high flammability, the anesthesiologist decides to discontinue its administration. The patient experiences a drop in blood pressure.

What is the most likely cause of the patient's hypotension?

choices.text: An equipment malfunction resulted in inadequate delivery of oxygen during surgery
Sudden withdrawal of cyclopropane led to a sharp decrease in sympathetic nervous system activity
The patient experienced a common side effect of the electrocautery
The patient had an allergic reaction to cyclopropane

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Sudden withdrawal of cyclopropane led to a sharp decrease in sympathetic nervous system activity

Explanation:

  • Cyclopropane is used as an inhalational general anaesthetic agent that increases blood pressure by stimulating the sympathetic nervous system.
  • Sudden discontinuation of cyclopropane can result in a rapid decrease in sympathetic activity, causing hypotension. This phenomenon is known as cyclopropane shock.

questions.text: Entonox, used for analgesia during painful procedures, exhibits the Poynting effect. Which of the following statements best describes the Poynting effect in Entonox?

choices.text: It causes the individual properties of nitrogen and oxygen to intensify when combined
It results in the production of a gas mixture that behaves differently from its individual components
It increases the likelihood of adverse effects when administering Entonox
It leads to the rapid separation of nitrogen and oxygen at high pressures

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) It results in the production of a gas mixture that behaves differently from its individual components

Explanation:

Entonox, a blend of nitrogen oxide (N2O) and oxygen in a 50:50 ratio, serves as an analgesic in both adults and children. Also used in labor.

  • Its production involves passing oxygen through liquid nitrogen oxide (N2O), where the gases mutually dissolve, resulting in a gas mixture that behaves as a single gas differently from its individual components, known as the "Poynting effect."
  • Entonox is presented as a gas in blue cylinders with white and blue checked shoulders.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with a history of substance abuse presents for a wisdom tooth extraction. The patient is known to abuse nitrous oxide recreationally. His medical history is otherwise unremarkable. The anesthesiologist is considering the use of nitrous oxide for sedation. Which of the following complications should the anesthesiologist be most concerned about for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Vitamin B 12 Deficiency

Explanation: 


Recreational abuse of nitrous oxide can lead to vitamin B12 deficiency, causing:

  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Myelopathy
  • Cognitive impairment

 

Malignant Hyperthermia (Option A): It is a rare but life-threatening complication typically associated with volatile anaesthetics such as halothane and depolarising muscle relaxants like succinylcholine, not with nitrous oxide.

 

Hepatotoxicity (Option B): It is a significant side effect of halothane and is not seen as associated with nitrous oxide.

The mechanism of halothane hepatotoxicity is by metabolic pathway and immune-mediated pathway.

Metabolic pathway:

  • Halothane is metabolized primarily in the liver by the cytochrome P450 enzyme system, into trifluoroacetic acid (TFA) producing reactive intermediates, such as trifluoroacetyl chloride, which can bind to hepatic proteins, forming neoantigens.

Immune-Mediated Response:

  • The neoantigens formed by the binding of reactive intermediates to liver proteins can trigger an immune response.
  • In susceptible individuals, this can lead to hepatic inflammation and injury known as halothane hepatitis.

Renal toxicity (Option D): It is seen with anaesthetics such as methoxyflurane and halothane and not with nitrous oxide.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset sharp chest pain and shortness of breath. On examination, he has decreased breath sounds on the left side, and chest X-ray confirms left-sided pneumothorax. The patient is scheduled for an urgent chest tube insertion under general anaesthesia. Which of the following inhaled anaesthetics is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Nitrous oxide

Explanation:

 

  • Nitrous oxide diffuses rapidly into air-filled spaces due to its low blood-gas solubility coefficient.
     
  • In a pneumothorax, this leads to expansion of the trapped air, worsening the condition and potentially leading to tension pneumothorax.
     
  • Therefore, it is absolutely contraindicated in conditions with air-containing spaces like:
     
    • Pneumothorax
       
    • Bowel obstruction
       
    • Middle ear surgeries
       
    • Intracranial air (post-neurosurgery)
       
    • Air embolism risk

questions.text:
Match each inhalation agent with its corresponding blood/gas partition coefficient:

 

 


	
		
			
			Inhaled anaesthetic 
			
			
			B/G partition coefficient
			
		
		
			
			a) Sevoflurane
			
			
			1) 0.47
			
		
		
			
			b) Isoflurane
			
			
			2) 0.68
			
		
		
			
			c) Desflurane
			
			
			3) 1.4
			
		
		
			
			d) Nitrous oxide
			
			
			4) 0.42
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) a-2, b-3, c-4, d-1

Explanation: 

The blood/gas partition coefficient is a measure of how soluble gas is in the blood. Lower values indicate faster induction and recovery times and helps minimize respiratory depression.

  • Desflurane has the lowest B/G coefficient (0.42).
    • It is the fastest-acting flurane.
    • For a patient with COPD, minimizing time spent under deep anesthesia is crucial, hence desflurane is preferred for rapid onset and offset of anesthesia.
  • Sevoflurane: B/G partition coefficient is 0.68.
  • Isoflurane: B/G partition coefficient is 1.4.
  • Nitrous Oxide: B/G partition coefficient is 0.47.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department with acute onset right lower quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. On examination, he has right lower quadrant rebound tenderness and guarding. The doctor decides to take him up for an emergency surgery.

Which inhalation anaesthetic would be best for induction in this patient based on its MAC values and blood gas solubility?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Sevoflurane

Explanation:

  • Sevoflurane has a moderate MAC value (2%) and is also preferred for its additional benefit of rapid induction and recovery times due to its relatively low blood-gas solubility.
  • The patient’s complaints and clinical features point towards the suspicion of Appendicitis. Hence, he is possibly being taken up for an emergency laparoscopic appendicectomy.
  • COMPOUND A of sevoflurane causes renal toxicity

 

MAC Definition:

The concentration of the general anaesthetic in the alveoli of the lung that produces unresponsiveness to the surgical incision in 50% of patients.

 

Nitrous oxide (Option A): It has a very high MAC value (105%) and is not potent enough to be used as a sole anaesthetic agent.

 

Desflurane (Option C): It has a MAC value of around 6%, so it is less potent than sevoflurane. However, it has a very rapid onset and offset, making it suitable for short procedures and outpatient surgeries.

 

Halothane (Option D): It has a very low MAC value (0.75%), indicating high potency, but it is associated with significant side effects, including hepatotoxicity, and is less commonly used today.
